keyword.en: Structure Analysis of Metals and Alloys
Structure Control of Metals and Alloys

paper_title.en: Upsetting properties in continuous casting and extruded bars of AZ91 magnesium alloy

publication_name.en: Keikinzoku/Journal of Japan Institute of Light Metals

paper_title.en: GRAIN REFINEMENT OF Mg-Al-Zn ALLOY BAR DURING HOT COMPRESSION

description.en: Grain refinements during hot compression of continuous casting AZ80 alloy bars and extrusive AZ61, AZ80 alloy bars were observed. The hot compression true stress-true strain curves of extrusive AZ61 and AZ80 alloy had similar tendencies, which were that the true stress increased and had a peak around 0.2 true strain, and then the stress decreased and was almost even from about 0.4 true strain. The stress peaks shifted to the high strain side as the compression speed, true strain speed, increased. However, the stress peaks did not shift at different compression temperatures. Fine grains were obtained under the condition of high strain speed and low temperature, but the grain sizes were uneven at low temperature compression. The stress peaks in the hot compression true stress-true strain curves of continuous casting AZ80 did not shift at different compression temperatures. AZ80 forging products with fine grains are expected to be formed under various conditions by using continuous casting AZ80.

paper_title.en: ROTARY-DIE EQUAL CHANNEL ANGULAR PRESSING METHOD FOR LIGHT METALS

description.en: A new ECAP process method called rotary-die ECAP (RD-ECAP) was developed to form fine-grained bulk materials such as aluminium alloys, magnesium alloys, aluminium composites, and titanium, all of which can be processed under conditions of 573-773K, at an approximately 0.9-24 mm/s punch speed of 300MPa or lower. By the RD-ECAP method, ECAP processing of up to 2 passes can be done without sample removal and samples processed over 30 cycles were obtained

paper_title.en: Improvement in strength and ductility of magnesium alloy parts by hot forging

publication_name.en: Keikinzoku/Journal of Japan Institute of Light Metals

paper_title.en: Nanoporous metals fabricated by dealloying; Morphological evolution and properties

description.en:
Dealloying is the selective dissolution of less noble metal from binary alloys, and can fabricate the nanoporous metals with an open-cell structure. The fabricated nanoporous metals are also regarded as composites made from metals and nanopores. We fabricated nanoporous Au, Pt, Pd and Ni by the dealloying of simple binary alloys. The dispersed open nanopores offer significant surface area, inducing many interesting properties which are not seen in the macroscopic porous metals having pore size above micrometers. Self-organization of the morphology of nanopores in the nanoporous metals, which can be induced by thermal treatments, is also shown. Thermal treatment coarsened the nanoporous structure via recrystallization. The nanosized porous structures also affect the mechanical properties
 the smaller the ligament size was, the higher the hardness was. This size dependence is also quite different from that for conventional porous metals.

publication_name.en: The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society - 3rd International Conference on Processing Materials for Properties 2008, PMP III

paper_title.en: Friction stir processing - A new technique for microstructure control of metallic materials

publication_name.en: Keikinzoku/Journal of Japan Institute of Light Metals

paper_title.en: Effects of homogenization treatment on mechanical properties of hot-rolled AZ31 magnesium alloy

description.en: The mechanical properties of the AZ31B alloy sheets processed by differential speed rolling (DSR) from the cast ingots homogenized at two different conditions were investigated. There still existed the uneven distribution of Al and Zn in the ingot homogenized at 673 K for 6 h, while it was homogeneous for the ingot homogenized at 723 K for 24 h. Compare with the sheet rolled from the ingot homogenized at 673 K for 6 h, the sheet rolled from the ingot homogenized at 723 K for 24 h exhibited a lower proof stress, a larger elongation, and a lager strain hardening exponent. The improvement in the ductility can be attributed to the elimination of the micro segregation of Al and Zn in the matrix.

publication_name.en: PRICM 6: SIXTH PACIFIC RIM INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON ADVANCED MATERIALS AND PROCESSING, PTS 1-3

paper_title.en: Effects of manganese on microstructure and mechanical properties of AZ31 magnesium alloy processed by differential speed rolling

description.en: A DSR processing with a roll speed ratio of 1.08 was carried out on an AZ31 alloys with Mn additions of 0, 0.2, 0.4 and 0.6 wt.% for investigating the effects of Mn on the microstructural evolution and mechanical properties. The amount of the Al-Mn compounds increased with increasing the Mn content. Compare with the DSR processed sheet without Mn addition with a homogeneous grain size, those with Mn additions exhibited an inhomogeneous microstructure due to the appearance of the shear bands comprising the small grains around 5 mu m. The Mn addition exhibited a significant effect in grain refinement even for a low content of 0.2 wt.%, which reduced the average grain size from about 25 mu m to 10 mu m. The Mn addition resulted in the significant increases in the tensile strength and the 0.2% proof stress by about 25 MPa and 40 MPa, respectively.

paper_title.en: Effects of differential speed rolling on microstructure and mechanical properties of AZ31 magnesium alloy

description.en: A differential speed rolling (DSR) processing with a roll speed ratio of 1.167 was carried out on an AZ31 alloy for investigating the effects of DSR on microstructure, texture and mechanical properties. The DSR processed sheet showed unidirectional shear bands with a small grain size of 5.5 mu m inclining to the rolling direction, and the basal plane tended to incline at about 15 degrees from the rolling plane toward the rolling direction. Compared with the normal rolled sheet, the DSR processed sheets showed a lower proof stress and a larger elongation with an increase from 21% to 26% in the rolling direction. The proof stress increased and the elongation decreased with the angle between the tensile direction and the rolling direction.

paper_title.en: Mechanical properties and formability of AZ31 magnesium alloy processed by differential speed rolling

description.en: An AZ31 (Mg-3Al-1Zn-0.35Mn in mass%) alloy sheet exhibiting the inclination of the basal plane from the rolling plane at about 15 degrees, was fabricated by a DSR processing with a roll speed ratio of 1.167. Compared with the normal rolled sheets, the DSR processed sheets showed a lower 0.2% proof stress, a larger elongation, a smaller r-value and a larger n-value. The Erichsen value at room temperature significantly increased from 2.2 to 3.1, and the deep drawability also improved.

paper_title.en: Microstructure and mechanical properties of SUS304L stainless steel processed by equal channel angular extrusion
Application of equal channel angular extrusion to the control of microstructure in stainless steels

description.en: Commercial stainless steels (SUS304L and SUS430) were subjected to equal channel angular extrusion (ECAE) at room temperature to a total strain of 2.3 to 9.2. For each type of stainless steel, it was shown that the sample processed by ECAE showed higher room temperature strength than the as-quenched sample. This is probably due to the heavily worked structure. On the other hand, both strength and elongation of the ECAE processed SUS430 were increased by annealing at 773K. It is likely that higher strength is attributed to both the heavily worked structure and fine substructures. It is also likely that higher elongation is attributed to the fine substructures. It is concluded that ECAE is available for improving the room temperature strength of commercial stainless steels.

publication_name.en: SECOND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON PROCESSING MATERIALS FOR PROPERTIES

publisher.ja: The Surface Finishing Society of Japan
publisher.en: The Surface Finishing Society of Japan

publication_name.ja: 表面技術 = The Journal of the Surface Finishing Society of Japan

paper_title.en: Grain boundary character distribution control of Al-Mg alloys by hot extrusion

description.en: In the present study, we tried to control GBCD of commercial 5056 Al alloy ( Al-5 mass% M g) by hot extrusion with various processing conditions. The fraction of low angle boundaries in 5056 Al alloy decreased as extrusion temperature increased from 473K to 873K. However, the fraction of coincidence boundaries (< Sigma 31) and random boundaries increased as extrusion temperature increased. It was found that the fraction of coincidence boundaries in the sample extruded at 873K was 14% which was about five times as large as that of the sample extruded at 473K. It was also found that annealing treatment after hot extrusion was effective for increasing the fraction of coincidence boundaries. As for the sample extruded at 673K followed by annealing at 873K, the fraction of coincidence boundaries was 17%. Microstructure observation showed that recrystallization and grain growth occurred in this sample. This result suggests that it is possible to control GBCD by using recrystallization and grain growth.

paper_title.ja: シリコンを用いたレーザアロイングによる工業用純チタンの表面改質
paper_title.en: Laser Surface Alloying of CP Titanium with Silicon

description.ja: Silicon powder was spread on the surfaces of CP Titanium plates and reacted with titanium by CO<sub>2</sub> laser irradiation, forming silicide layers 600μm or thicker on the plates. Most alloy layers consisted of Ti<sub>5</sub>Si<sub>3</sub>. The highest hardness was 10GPa, and abrasion loss was 50-60% less than that of pure titanium.
description.en: Silicon powder was spread on the surfaces of CP Titanium plates and reacted with titanium by CO<sub>2</sub> laser irradiation, forming silicide layers 600μm or thicker on the plates. Most alloy layers consisted of Ti<sub>5</sub>Si<sub>3</sub>. The highest hardness was 10GPa, and abrasion loss was 50-60% less than that of pure titanium.

paper_title.ja: ほう酸アルミニウムウィスカ強化６０６１アルミニウム合金の機械的性質に及ぼす熱処理の効果
paper_title.en: Effect of heat treatment on the mechanical properties of aluminum-borate whisker reinforced 6061 aluminum alloy.

description.ja: Effect of heat treatment (solution treatment and aging treatment at 443K) on the tensile strength between room temperature and 773K was investigated of the aluminum-borate whisker reinforced (Vf=0.16 and 0.29) 6061 aluminum alloys. Tensile strength of the as-cast 0.29 Vf composite is in the measured temperature range about twice higher than that of the matrix alloy. No whiskers are observed on the fracture surfaces of the composites up to 573K. Both tensile strengths of the matrix alloy and of the 0.29 Vf composite are increased by aging treatment. The degree of the increase is, however, smaller for the composite than the matrix alloy. In the heat-treated composites, whiskers are observed on the fracture surfaces. This result shows that the strength of matrix alloy/whisker interface is decreased by the heat treatment.
description.en: Effect of heat treatment (solution treatment and aging treatment at 443K) on the tensile strength between room temperature and 773K was investigated of the aluminum-borate whisker reinforced (Vf=0.16 and 0.29) 6061 aluminum alloys. Tensile strength of the as-cast 0.29 Vf composite is in the measured temperature range about twice higher than that of the matrix alloy. No whiskers are observed on the fracture surfaces of the composites up to 573K. Both tensile strengths of the matrix alloy and of the 0.29 Vf composite are increased by aging treatment. The degree of the increase is, however, smaller for the composite than the matrix alloy. In the heat-treated composites, whiskers are observed on the fracture surfaces. This result shows that the strength of matrix alloy/whisker interface is decreased by the heat treatment.

publication_name.en: Journal of Japan Institute of Light Metals

paper_title.en: Surface hardening of CP titanium by laser alloying process

description.en: In order to improve a surface hardness of commercially pure titanium, surface alloying with laser was carried out. Pure silicon, nickel, aluminum powder and a mixture of silicon and 9 mass%WSi2 powder were used for surface alloying. These powders were spread on surfaces of titanium plates and reacted with titanium by CO2 laser beam. Laser irradiation was carried out in argon atmosphere. As a result, when the silicon powder was used, a hard silicide layer (a principal ingredient was Ti5Si3) was formed over thickness 600 μm. In the case of the nickel powder, an alloying layer was consisted of TiNi and Ti2Ni, and its highest hardness was HV600. When the aluminum powder was used, needle-like shapes of precipitates of TiAl3 were observed in aluminum-rich matrix phase. Moreover, in alloying with the powder mixture of silicon and WSi2 powder, concentration phase of tungsten that had over HV1500 hardness were observed locally.

publication_name.en: Keikinzoku/Journal of Japan Institute of Light Metals

paper_title.ja: Optimization method of FGM compositional distribution profile design by genetic algorithm
paper_title.en: Optimization method of FGM compositional distribution profile design by genetic algorithm

description.ja: The automatic compositional distribution profile design system for functionally graded material is proposed. This system optimizes the compositional distribution profile to satisfy requirements. The system consists of the Analyzer and the Optimizer. As an illustration, the design system is applied to thermal stress relaxation problem.
description.en: The automatic compositional distribution profile design system for functionally graded material is proposed. This system optimizes the compositional distribution profile to satisfy requirements. The system consists of the Analyzer and the Optimizer. As an illustration, the design system is applied to thermal stress relaxation problem.

paper_title.ja: Joining of a Si-Ti-C-O fiber-bonded ceramic and an Fe-Cr-Ni stainless steel with a Ag-Cu-Ti brazing alloy
paper_title.en: Joining of a Si-Ti-C-O fiber-bonded ceramic and an Fe-Cr-Ni stainless steel with a Ag-Cu-Ti brazing alloy

description.ja: Joining of a Si-Ti-C-O fiber-bonded ceramic and an Fe-Cr-Ni stainless steel with a Ag-Cu-Ti brazing alloy was carried out. For relaxation of thermal stress caused by thermal expansion mismatch between the ceramic and the stainless steel, a thin pure copper plate was set between the specimens to be joined. Joining strength was evaluated by a four-point bending test at room temperature. The highest strength of ceramic/ stainless steel joint attained in this study was 230 MPa. The scattering of the strength was narrow. The ceramic-side fracture surfaces of the joints were divided into many reglons by fiber/matrix interfacial cracks. It was inferred that those fiber/matrix interfacial cracks, which were perpendicular to the main crack along the joining interface, decreased the stress intensity factor of the main crack and increased the strength of the joint.
description.en: Joining of a Si-Ti-C-O fiber-bonded ceramic and an Fe-Cr-Ni stainless steel with a Ag-Cu-Ti brazing alloy was carried out. For relaxation of thermal stress caused by thermal expansion mismatch between the ceramic and the stainless steel, a thin pure copper plate was set between the specimens to be joined. Joining strength was evaluated by a four-point bending test at room temperature. The highest strength of ceramic/ stainless steel joint attained in this study was 230 MPa. The scattering of the strength was narrow. The ceramic-side fracture surfaces of the joints were divided into many reglons by fiber/matrix interfacial cracks. It was inferred that those fiber/matrix interfacial cracks, which were perpendicular to the main crack along the joining interface, decreased the stress intensity factor of the main crack and increased the strength of the joint.

paper_title.en: The aging behavior and the mechanical properties of the Mg-Li-Al-Cu alloy
The aging behavior and the mechanical properties of the Mg-Li-Al-Cu alloy

paper_title.ja: Deflection of a main crack along a weak plane consisting of a group of preexisting cracks in a silicon nitride ceramic
paper_title.en: Deflection of a main crack along a weak plane consisting of a group of preexisting cracks in a silicon nitride ceramic

description.ja: Deflection of a main crack along an artificially formed weak plane consisting of a group of preexisting cracks in a sillicon nitride ceramic, was studied experimentally. The weak planes inside the ceramics were formed by diffusion joining of the ceramics. Main cracks were produced by indentation. Deflection of a main crack was related to the strength of a joining interface. A weak joining interface could cause deflection of a main crack, and strengthen a specimen with an initial main crack. A main crack passed across a strong interface and caused catastrophic failure.
description.en: Deflection of a main crack along an artificially formed weak plane consisting of a group of preexisting cracks in a sillicon nitride ceramic, was studied experimentally. The weak planes inside the ceramics were formed by diffusion joining of the ceramics. Main cracks were produced by indentation. Deflection of a main crack was related to the strength of a joining interface. A weak joining interface could cause deflection of a main crack, and strengthen a specimen with an initial main crack. A main crack passed across a strong interface and caused catastrophic failure.

publication_name.ja: Journal of the Ceramic Society of Japan
publication_name.en: Journal of the Ceramic Society of Japan

paper_title.en: Effect of aging treatment on the mechanical properties of the Mg-Li-Al-Cu alloy

description.en: Age hardening behavior and the mechanical properties of the Mg-37.5at%Li-0.7at%Al-0.4at%Cu alloy alloys were investigated. After the peak-aging treatment at 300K (room temperature), the ultimate tensile stress of this alloy increased to 198 MPa with a large elongation of 15 %. It is concluded that this significant increase in ultimate tensile stress after aging at 300K is due to the fine precipitated particles by the peak-aging treatment.

publication_name.en: THERMEC '97 - INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON THERMOMECHANICAL PROCESSING OF STEELS AND OTHER MATERIALS, VOLS I-II

paper_title.en: Effect of alloying elements on the ageing behaviour of a Mg-Li-Al alloy

description.en: Effect of copper on the ageing behaviour of a Mg-38at.%Li-0.7at.%Al alloy was investigated. Copper was chosen as the alloying element, because it is not soluble in Mg and is expected to act as the nucleation sites for precipitates. After peak-ageing at room temperature (300 K), fine particles were precipitated in the Mg-Li-Al alloy by the addition of copper. Ultimate tensile stress of the peak-aged Mg-Li-Al-Cu alloy was 198 MPa, which was about 1.8 times higher than that of the as-cast Mg-Li-Al alloy.

publication_name.en: PROCEEDINGS OF THE THIRD INTERNATIONAL MAGNESIUM CONFERENCE

paper_title.en: Effects of small addition of titanium, vanadium and chromium on the kinetics of ε-carbide precipitation in high purity Fe-C alloys

description.en: The effects of small additions of titanium, vanadium and chromium on the rate of ε-carbide precipitation is investigated in high purity alloys made from 99.99% electrolytic iron. The kinetics of the carbide precipitation was investigated by measuring at 77 K the change in the electrical resistivity due to precipitation. The number of density precipitates was investigated by TEM. The activation energy for carbon atom diffusion was determined by the slope change method. Results show that only titanium increases the rate of carbide precipitation.

paper_title.en: Effects of small addition of titanium, vanadium and chromium on the kinetics of ε-carbide precipitation in high purity Fe-C alloys

description.en: The effects of small additions of titanium, vanadium and chromium on the rate of ε-carbide precipitation is investigated in high purity alloys made from 99.99% electrolytic iron. The kinetics of the carbide precipitation was investigated by measuring at 77 K the change in the electrical resistivity due to precipitation. The number of density precipitates was investigated by TEM. The activation energy for carbon atom diffusion was determined by the slope change method. Results show that only titanium increases the rate of carbide precipitation.

paper_title.en: Effect of silicon on the kinetics of ε-carbide precipitation in high purity Fe-C alloys

description.en: Silicon is known to decrease the precipitation rate of ε-carbide. However, the cause of silicon decreasing the rate of ε-carbide precipitation has not been determined yet. The purpose of the present paper is to clarify this cause, especially the relationship between the number density of ε-carbide particles and the rate of its precipitation. High purity alloys made from 99.99% electrolytic iron were used in the present paper to minimize the effect of impurity atoms on the precipitation kinetics of ε-carbide as low as possible. The kinetics of ε-carbide precipitation was investigated by measuring the change in electrical resistivity at 77 K. The number density of ε-carbide particles was investigated by TEM. Silicon decreases the rate of ε-carbide precipitation. This decrease is caused by the decrease in the number density of ε-carbide particles with the addition of silicon. Comparing the precipitation rate of Fe-C alloys with that of the Fe-0.4 at.%Si-C alloy, it is concluded that the heterogeneous nucleation occurs in the present Fe-C alloy. That is, silicon decreases the number of the preferred nucleation sites of ε-carbides and hence the number of the ε-carbide particles.

publisher.en: Publ by Japan Inst of Metals
